abstractText: We propose a computational framework to study the effect of corrosion on the mechanical strength of m samples. Our work is motivated by the need to predict the residual strength of biomedical Mg implants afte of degradation in a physiological environment. To model corrosion, a mass-diffusion type model is used th localised corrosion using Weibull statistics. The overall mass loss is prescribed (e.g., based on experime mechanical behaviour of the Mg samples is modeled by a state-of-the-art Cazacu-Plunkett-Barlat plastic a coupled damage model. This allowed us to study how Mg degradation in immersed samples reduces strength over time. We performed a large number of in vitro corrosion experiments and mechanical tests computational framework. Our framework could predict both the experimentally observed loss of mechani the ductility due to corrosion for both tension and compression tests.

Strength and Ductility Loss of Magnesium-Gadolinium due to Corros Physiological Environment: Experiments and Modeling
Dirk Steglicha,∗, Jacques Bessonb, Inken Reinkea, Heike Helmholzc, Monika Luczakc, Vasil M. Garamusc Daniel Höched, Christian J. Cyrona,e, Regine Willumeit-Römerc
aInstitute of Material Systems Modeling, Helmholtz-Zentrum Hereon, Max-Planck-Str. 1, 21502 Geesthacht, Germa bCentre des Matériaux, PSL Research University, Mines ParisTech, UMR CNRS 7633, BP 87, 91003 Evry Cedex, Fr
cInstitute of Metallic Biomaterials, Helmholtz-Zentrum Hereon, Max-Planck-Str. 1, 21502 Geesthacht, Germany dInstitute of Surface Science, Helmholtz-Zentrum Hereon, Max-Planck-Str. 1, 21502 Geesthacht, Germany
eInstitute for Continuum and Material Mechanics, Hamburg University of Technology, Eissendorfer Str. 42, 21073 Hambur
Abstract
We propose a computational framework to study the effect of corrosion on the mechanical strength of m samples. Our work is motivated by the need to predict the residual strength of biomedical Mg implants afte of degradation in a physiological environment. To model corrosion, a mass-diffusion type model is used th localised corrosion using Weibull statistics. The overall mass loss is prescribed (e.g., based on experime mechanical behaviour of the Mg samples is modeled by a state-of-the-art Cazacu-Plunkett-Barlat plastic a coupled damage model. This allowed us to study how Mg degradation in immersed samples reduces strength over time. We performed a large number of in vitro corrosion experiments and mechanical tests computational framework. Our framework could predict both the experimentally observed loss of mechani the ductility due to corrosion for both tension and compression tests. Keywords: Biodegradable magnesium, Finite elements, Damage modeling, Corrosion localisation, Mass

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Magnesium (Mg) and its alloys are becoming increasingly popular as alternatives to permanent im due to their biodegradability, biocompatibility and ability to promote bone growth. Not only is the pro ibility beneficial for tissue regeneration and consequently medical applications but also the documented and anti-inflammatory effects [1]. Mg alloys have better mechanical properties and a better degradation biodegradable polymers. Since the typically used alloying element Aluminium can be potentially neuroto
∗Corresponding author Email address: dirk.steglich@hereon.de (Dirk Steglich)
Preprint submitted to Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
esium alloys in tion behaviour, roperties [2, 3] fic applications10 as observed for ]. g up the develegradation have dels. Dahms et15 electrochemical (CDM) models [10] used CDM oach allows for y of the overall20 de the corrosive l processes that combination of a was described ction of tensile25 aims at extendfunction of the llowing, a mass scribed in [13], by a mass loss30 a configuration, anical strength the mentioned ile the first one on. of are exploring the use of other alloying elements for implant materials. The use of aluminium-free magn biomedical implants depends on specific material properties, such as good biocompatibility, robust degrada and suitable mechanical properties. Mg-Gd alloys have shown promising potential in terms of mechanical p and in vitro and in vivo biocompatibility testing [4? ? –6]. Tailoring suitable degradation kinetics for speci remains the focus of current research. In the case of binary Mg-Gd alloys, a minimum corrosion rate w Mg-10Gd [2] in aerated 1% NaCl solution. At higher concentrations of Gd, the corrosion rate increased [7
Computational modeling can be used to make predictions based on in vitro experiments, thus speedin opment process of new implants if reliable models are developed. Various computational models of Mg d been published to date, including physical, phenomenological, analytical, and machine learning-based mo al. [8] presented a simplified model based on the mass conservation law, but did not include chemical and processes due to the analytical nature of the approach. Other studies used continuum damage mechanics to describe the effect of Mg degradation on a phenomenological level. Gastaldi et al. [9] and Grogan et al. models to simulate the diffusion-controlled degradation of Mg-based absorbable stents. The CDM appr the study of the micro-scale geometric discontinuities induced by degradation on the mechanical integrit specimen without explicitly modeling the moving boundary. For addressing the latter, it is required to inclu medium in the analysis, see e.g. [11]. In any case, these approaches do not consider the electrochemica occur during degradation, which may vary locally. As a result, CDMmodel needs to be calibrated for each corrosive environment and material composition. A method for experimentally generating the required dat by Boland et al. [12] for the magnesium alloy WE43. The authors successfully predicted the strength redu samples as a function of the mass loss caused by in vitro degradation. In the same spirit, the present work ing the predictive capabilities of numerical tools towards the ductility quantified by the failure strain as a corrosion time. Corrosion is regarded as initiation for strain localisation and damage initiation. In the fo diffusion type analysis is utilised to model the degradation of a Mg-10Gd alloy. Similar to the procedure de a concentration field representing Faraday’s dissolution-related phase change of magnesium is simulated analysis and subsequently mapped to a variable affecting the local strength in the domain. Based on such a finite element simulation of compression tests and tensile tests is performed to analyse the global mech of the sample that remains at the given point in time due to the corrosion up to that point. In contrast to work, here, the local strength loss and the damage variable are considered in general as independent. Wh is directly taken from the mass loss analysis, the latter evolves during loading in the mechanical simulati for the realistic incorporation of surface defects resulting from corrosion into a simulation model, facilitat of their effects on the mechanical behaviour of standard samples.

sections.heading: 2. Material
sections.text: TheMg alloy with 10 wt%Gd (Mg-10Gd) was produced by direct chill casting followed by solid solutio and in-direct extrusion as described by [3]. In contrast to the previous work, a round bar of 6 mm was parameters were chosen so that the properties are comparable to the material extruded at 400 °C with a 3.3 m/min. The exit speed was identical to that of 10 mm rods and adjusted due to the different extrusion r this material was extruded at 0.8 mm/s with an extrusion ratio of 1:69 at 400 °C. Run-in and run-out of the cut and not used in the following.

sections.heading: 3. Experiments
sections.text:
To quantify the corrosion and its effect on the mechanical behaviour, two different sample geometries w prismatic bars (4 mm×4 mm×8 mm), and prismatic sticks (2 mm×2 mm ×50 mm), similar to those used in one served two purposes: it was used during immersion tests to determine the mass loss as a function of tim subsequent compression testing. The latter served as a tool to characterise the tensile properties of the cor Some samples were further examined before mechanical testing by computed tomography (CT). The samp in the following as immersion bars (IB) and tensile sticks (TS), respectively. All samples were machined fro the extruded rod with identical machining parameters to achieve reproducible and comparable surface qual referred to as "as-received" in the following. It is the typical status prior to mechanical testing, but not suite experiments. The latter required a more specific surface preparation, see the following section.
A subset of IB samples were quasi–statically compressed up to a strain of 10% to investigate the e deformation on the corrosion rate. These samples are referred to as "predeformed" in the following. Tabl the number of samples and the different stages of immersion considered.

In preparation, the ends of the tensile sticks were protected with 5mm heat-shrink tubing before sterilisation
The immersion test was performed under sterile and physiological conditions at 37 ◦C, 5% CO2, 19.7% tive humidity. The immersion medium consisted of DMEM+Glutamax Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Med Glucose (Life Technologies), 10%Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS, SigmaAldrich ChemieGmbH) and 1%Penici (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc.). To optimise the immersion vessel regarding the specimens’ geometry, bricks were placed in 12-well microtiter plates in 3mL; the tensile sticks were placed in T25 cell culture As the immersion test was pursued in a semi-static manner, the medium was changed twice a week for on The pH value and osmolality were monitored during media exchange. Additionally, the released Mg io was determined in the immersion medium supernatant by atomic absorption spectroscopy as described [18] using a flame AAS (Agilent 240 AA, Agilent Technologies) at a wavelength of 285.2 nm. A calibratio from 0.05 to 1.00mg/L Mg was applied for quantification.
After the immersion test, the degradation products of the immersion brickswere removedwith chromic a for 10min 180 g/L Chromium(VI) oxide in ultra pure water) to calculate their mass loss. Before and after the weights of the immersion bricks were measured with an electronic balance (SBA 32, accuracy 0.1 Instruments GmbH). sections.heading: 3.2. Computed Tomography
sections.text:
The X-ray computed tomography (CT) scans were performed on selected TS samples with the CT sc Cougar (YXLON International GmbH). The scanner was equipped with an area detector of 1004×1004 pix size of 0.127mm. During the scans, the samples rotated around the longitudinal axis. A compromise b information and spatial resolution was made for the scanned volume. The scanned volume of the tensile s the central part with the length of 25mm. Five of the immersion bricks (4mm × 4mm × 8mm) were s to verify the segmentation (grey level). The immersion bricks were completely displayed by the CT scan conditions were applied during all CT scans: voltage 60 kV, current 55 A with 1200 projections (3 re obtained voxel sizes were 0.0263mm (tensile sticks) and 0.0149mm (immersion bricks), respectively. Nex were converted into a suitable format for further analysis. The CT scans were reconstructed with the YX spooler and converted into a DICOM format (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine) by VG (Volume Graphics GmbH, Heidelberg, Germany). The software Simpleware (Synopsys, Inc.) was used to segment the reconstructed CT scans. Before segmentation, all scans were aligned and cropped to reduce t To segment the scans, multi-level Otsu segmentation was used that selects an optimal threshold with discri applied on the histogram [19]. Three masks were chosen for segmenting the tensile stick scans, see Fig. represented the corroded sample (Mg-10Gd) (yellow), the corrosion product (green) and the surrounding a For the immersion bricks, only two masks were chosen because the corrosion product was removed from quently, an FE discretisation was created in Simpleware with the mask of the corroded sample (Mg-10Gd) was exported to Abaqus via a standard input file (*.inp).

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical Testing
sections.text:
The tensile tests were conducted on a Zwick Roell Z0101 machine at a speed of 2 mm/min, with a ma 2500 N and a preload of 0.3 N. While the force signal was acquired by the load cell, the displacement sign with the help of Electronic Speckle Pattern Interferometry, with a gauge length of appr x. 6.5 mm. A cross-head displacement was recorded. In the case of IB compression tests, a Schenck servo-hydraulic 10 was used. Load was applied via mirror-polished parallel plates in axial direction, with a cross-head speed Two extensometers were used to measure the relative displacement of the plates. The average of their readi calculate the displacement along the compression direction. Stresses and strains reported in the following as normalised forces (i.e., force divided by the initial cross-section) and strains as length change divide length. Hence, they constitute global quantities, characterising samples as a whole.
To verify that the tests performed with our special sample geometries were mechanically meaningfu results comparable to those of tests with standard sample geometries, a comparison on the basis of the as-re was performed. Standard samples (smooth round bars and compression cylinders) were machined fro material. Figure 2 shows the results of tensile and compression tests performed on standard samples samples used here. Apparently, the mechanical behaviour of both was nearly identical over a large strain strain localisation is favoured in the case of TS and IB samples, these samples only failed at lower strains c standard samples.

sections.heading: 4. Modeling
sections.text:
Four subsequent steps were conducted to identify the data required to numerically predict the time–dep loss. The strength loss is caused by uniform and localised degradation:
• Determination of the elastic–plastic behaviour of the as-received material by FE-simulations of ten pression tests (no corrosion),
• Mapping of the shape of corroded tensile samples determined by CT scans to respective FE-model and discretisation of the remaining metal, simulation of the individual tensile tests,
• Prediction of the remaining metallic magnesium in the samples as a function of time by phenome loss analyses, mapping of the magnesium concentration fields at distinct instances in time during period to fields generating a mechanical effect,

For the two latter points, statistical effects were investigated by considering Weibull-distributions of leading to localisation of mass loss, one cause for pitting corrosion [20]. The description of pitting corrosio via Weibull statistics was discussed by [21]. The flow of data described above is depicted in fig. 3.

sections.heading: 4.1. Mechanical Behaviour: Plasticity and Damage
sections.text:
Tensile and compression tests of the as-received material were used to calibrate a plasticity model. Due induced asymmetry in tension and compression, the Cazacu-Plunkett-Barlat (CPB)-model [22] was selecte the irreversible time–independent deformation. Since the extrusion direction (ED) was the main loading d information on other deformation modes apart from tension/compression along the EDwas available, the or version of the CPB-model was used. The CPB-model was combined with a damage model on the basis of a approach to predict damage nucleation and failure numerically. To this end, the effective stress of the C used to define a yield surface by a plastic potential

sections.heading: 4.2. Diffusion-type Model for Mass Loss Prediction
sections.text:
The corrosion process was simulated by means of a three-dimensional diffusion-based model. The di representing the faradaic dissolution of magnesium samples was simulated through the finite element me to Fick’s second law
)c )t = D Δc ,
where c is the magnesium concentration, t the time, D the coefficient of isotropic diffusion and Δ the La Following the procedure outlined in [10, 25], nodal concentration fluxes Ji on the surface of the samples w with the use of the probability density function q of the Weibull distribution and a scaling factor to sim and pitting corrosion. The concentration fluxes Ji act as Neumann boundary conditions of the diffusion negative sign represents the flow direction out of the solid:
Ji = − q(xi) with
q(xi) = a ( xi )a−1 exp (−(xi)a) ,
with a being the shape parameter of the distribution. To achieve a prescribed mass loss at a given time in the simulation, the scaling factor was introduc calculated via ∑ i Ji = Jtar . Jtar is the target overall flux preset and defines the integral/summation of all nodal fluxes. The concentr connected to the change in concentration by Fick’s law, Eq. (6). On this basis, the concentration at every in of each element can be calculated as a function of time. The global mass loss can be determined from the concentration ci and volume Vi in the integration points of the elements. The outcome is the amount of sub particular integration point. Summing up the amount of substance of each integration point results in the of substance at time t.

The total amount of substance of a body, n(t), is calculated as the sum of individual concentrations an
n(t) = ∑ i ci(t) Vi H ( ci(t) − cMgGd ) ,
with H being the Heaviside function. The amount of substance at time t = 0 is used as a reference an nstart . The mass loss, Δmm0 (t), is therefore calculated from:
Δm m0 (t) = nstart − n(t) nstart .
By iteratively simulating the mass diffusion process with different scale factors , a given mass loss c that depends on the Weibull distribution. This procedure was implemented using a Python code together Element Suite ABAQUS/Standard [26].

sections.heading: 4.3. Simulation of Strength Loss and Failure
sections.text:
This section describes a procedure to predict the strength loss of arbitrary three-dimensional solids du It aims at replacing the scanning process described in chapter 3.2 by exploiting the diffusion model. As s discretisation of the corroded sample becomes obsolete, and a mechanical simulation can be conducted on initial geometry by using a damage model. sections.heading: 4.4. Finite Element Models
sections.text:
For the simulation of themass loss due to diffusion and for themechanical analysis, identical spatial disc used for each sample. The IB geometry was homogeneously meshed using 128,000 8-node diffusion ele in ABAQUS) for the corrosion analysis and 8-node stress-strain elements with selective integration for t analysis with Z-set. For the mechanical analysis, displacements were prescribed on the quadratic faces of to the (x,y)-plane, A and A′, see Fig. 4. Reaction forces were recorded from these nodes. The strain was these displacements normalised by the initial length of 8 mm.
For the tension analyses, typical plane dog-bone samples were considered in the simulations. In the are referred to as micro flat tensile samples (MFT). Note that their geometry was different from the one of used in the experiments. The reason for this difference was that we sought to avoid numerically trigge effects expected for exactly prismatic geometries. Shoulder regions ensure that load transfer is sufficiently gauge section. Additional geometrical imperfections were not used. Diffusion and tensile analyses used with 71,660 8-node diffusion elements (DC3D8 in ABAQUS) and 8-node stress-strain elements with selec for the tension analysis. Since the shoulders of the MFT samples solely serve as load transmitters, the diffusion analysis is irrelevant. Therefore, nodal fluxes were only applied on the four faces of the prisma Fig. 4. Axial displacements were applied for the simulation of the tensile tests on the shoulder surfaces fig. 4. The reaction forces divided by the initial cross section constituted the stress signal. The strain was the displacement difference in the parallel section. The failure strain was defined as the strain at maximu of each sample. Since the material does not show severe necking in tension, this definition leads to sim considering the elongation at fracture.

sections.heading: 5.1. Assessment of experimental Results on Mg-10Gd Degradation
sections.text:
The morphologies and types of used specimens result in a different degradation behaviour. One repres sion brick sample has been selected and is shown in Fig. 5. This sample is representative of most corro bricks as it has small pits all over its surface leading to a nearly homogeneous degradation after five weeks the degradation behaviour of the tensile sticks qualitatively, the geometry as well as the ratio of surface to be considered. Opposite to the compact geometry of the immersion bricks, the tensile sticks are elongate surface area exposed to the immersion medium. Pitting corrosion and breaks of specimens were obser which prevented a comprehensive investigation.
The degradation of the immersion bricks was quantified via mass loss and release of Mg during de five weeks. Fig. 6a shows the relative mass loss of immersion bricks increasing from a median of 0.8% to a maximum of 3.5% over the corrosion time of five weeks. This was observed for both as prepared predeformed immersion bricks (def, red). Note that most recorded data points are close to each other in group, which results in small standard deviations where these were not boosted by outliers, compare Fig. 6 median values were observed for the as-prepared and predeformed immersion bricks.
In addition to the mass loss, the Mg release and the corrosion rate, which is based on the mass los Fig. 6b. Fig. 6b illustrates the fast degradation during the first week followed by an almost constant releas week. The variance of values increased within the progress of the immersion test. sections.heading: 5.2. Parameter Calibration for the as-received Material
sections.text:
FE simulations were conducted for IB and MFT samples to describe the observed measured force–di haviour of the as-received material. From the tensile test, at first the parameters of the hardening law calibrated. Second, the parameter k describing the strength differential effect in Eq. (3) was determined the compression test. Finally, the parameters of the damage model were set to meet the failure point obse sile tests. Table 2 shows the parameters producing the simulation results depicted in Fig. 7. Since the he samples were included in the FE model, strain localisation occurs diagonally in the central region of the s caused by slightly elevated strain in the middle and subsequent damage at that position. For more details on behaviour, readers are referred to [28], which analyses discretisation effects and model symmetries.

is particularly relevant [30]. However, the selection of physiological test conditions and media increases th the system. The immersion in a cell culture medium provides small negatively and positively charged ion compounds as well as large peptides and proteins. All these components relate to different effects on th behaviour. A highCl− content accelerates the corrosion,CO3− bind freeMg2+ ions and form less soluble c Most importantly, the interaction of material surface with proteins, which are introduced by the fetal serum complexation ofCa2+ and the formation of amore or less stable protection layer whichmay reduce the degra 33]. Due to such complex interactions, the sensitivity of the test system to variations of the degradation cond compared to single salt solutions and ambient conditions. Standards were defined for testing the imme of metallic medical devices in electrolytes as ISO 10993-15 standard [34], ASTM NACE/ASTM G31-12 ISO10933 part 12 for non flat, irregular samples. In the present study, the conditions were selected accordin adapted. Immersion conditions were kept constant and equalled an electrolyte volume to test specimen su of 0.125 mL∕mm2 for the IB samples, and to 0.020 ml∕mm2 for the TS samples. This represents a comp covering the whole sample body with a sufficient amount of immersion medium and meeting the recomme mentioned guidelines. Nevertheless, differences in the corrosion behaviour between the IB and TS samples The more pronounced local degradation of the TS compared to the IB might be attributed to the different vo ratio. In semi-static degradation tests, less volume per surface (ratio between test solution volume and test sp area) leads to a faster increase in pH, which promotes dense deposit layer formation and subsequently sh degradation rate [35]. As pit initiation statistics very much vary with the alloying element distribution,

of effects as well as surface defects, it is still possible to observe high degradation rates despite electrolyte and Within this study it was observed that corrosion was suppressed in 3.5% NaCl solutions at pH values Localised corrosion did not appear as already shown by Zeng et al. [36]. However, the cited work show of pH values on the distribution and morphology of corrosion pits. High pH values lead to more local co formation, limited by pH=12, above which corrosion was suppressed. This effect seems to be also existen work, where the rapid increase in pH in the case of TS samples lead to severe local corrosion.
Due to the described differences in corrosion localisation, it was not expected that an identical Weib of fluxes, as considered in the case of IB samples, would produce the same results as the mechanical TS/MFT samples. Apparently, such reuse of Weibull parameters is generally not possible even if the deg are comparable. Due to the high sensitivity of the pit initiation mechanisms to small variations within th morphology as well as to the local electrolyte conditions, the application of IB/TS calibrated values to the M in general, not possible. If the degradation , in particular, becomes more heterogeneous, this aspect has to b As a consequence and as described in section 5.5, a = 0.01 was chosen to adequately simulate the loca scenario of the tensile samples. To quantify the effect of the Weibull statistics, a numerical study was MFT sample was seeded for mass diffusion (weight loss) analyses with four different Weibull distribution a = 1.0, a = 0.5, a = 0.1, and a = 0.01. For each case, 10 realisations were generated, leading to 40 simu The fluxes were iteratively determined such that they resulted in the same global mass loss in all cases. O sections of the sample were considered to be affected by corrosion. One realization for each of the abov distributions is depicted in Fig. 12. Although the position of the nodal fluxes was randomly chosen in the p the simulations are comparable in the sense that the corrosion conditions were identical. The results of mechanical analyses are depicted in Fig. 13. With increasing localisation, a = 1.0 → 0.01, the maximum by 52%. At the same time, the variation increases. Even more pronounced is the reduction of ductilit the average strain at maximum stress. Even for the "smooth" Weibull distribution of a = 1.0, an avera ductility compared to the one of the as-received material of 49% is calculated. a = 0.01 renders a reduc essence, a high localisation level of corrosion leads to a moderate stress reduction, but to a drastic loss of principle, this is neither a contradiction nor surprising: Due to the low strain-hardening of the material, s stress lead to large variations in strain. This is common for as-received material, but it also applies to co with non-uniform cross-sections.
The effect of the damage variable d in the analyses of failure is illustrated in Fig. 14. The mapped fie product fOx (see Fig. 14a) has two main effects on mechanics. First, it reduces the transfer of stresses via E due to the in-homogeneity of the field, it triggers strain localisation in the remainingmetallic material. The l

damage evolution, Eq. 5, and finally causes cracks to develop from the surface, see Fig. 14b. By this intera of corrosion pitting can be accounted for in the mechanical model. Although the described model is of phe nature, it appears to be versatile and hence useful for the assessment of medical implants undergoing corr that the results of this in vitro study can be generalised towards in vivo problems. In the current mathematic it is capable of covering the whole range from perfectly uniform degradation to statistically distributed p and its superposition. Intergranular effects as well as effects related to hydrogen uptake are not explicitl they are intrinsically included by the domain damage approach.
Commonly, FE analyses based on coupled damage models leading to material softening as utilized mesh dependency. Therefore, in the computational study a dependency of results on the discretisation is increasing mesh refinement for a given element formulation, the localisation zone becomes smaller. Hence energy decreases with decreasing element size. While this effect has significant impact in the case of fra simulations, the influence in the case of tensile samples is less pronounced [37]. Further, for the diffusi expected that a higher density of nodes affects the degree of localisation of corrosion. To quantify both current model, simulations of mass diffusion and tension are conducted for a mesh with 563,400 elements 71,660 elements for the simulations described above) for one realisation of the Weibull distribution with

result of the mechanical analysis is included in Fig. 13a by green open symbols. The stress–strain behaviou the one obtained with the coarser mesh. The predicted ductility falls in the strain interval given by the oth It can therefore be concluded that the conditions of equal mass loss lead to comparable results in case the changed.
The damage model, Eqs. 2 and 5, is kept as simple as possible here. The assumed damage nucleation depends on the plastic strain. The damage growth rate does not depend on the stress triaxiality. Conseque does not consider the growth and coalescence of voids and defects. The well–known triaxiality–depend in ductile metals [38] cannot be described. This simplification, however, appears acceptable, since failu corroded samples happens at the surface where the triaxiality equals 1∕3. It is further in line with observ other magnesium wrought alloys, for which strain–based failure models revealed quantitatively good resul parameter calibration presented here is robust, since it is possible to predict failure both in tension and com that the latter is triggered by a plastic instability, which depends on the length-to-width ratio of the com (IB: 2:1).
The application of the model to other Mg alloys is possible. It has to be considered that the intensity o depends on the alloying elements (see e.g. [41]), and its distribution. For example, calcium addition enha corrosion resistance of magnesium alloys significantly, and the surface properties as well [12]. In paralle of grinded and not grinded samples of the same alloy revealed a delay of corrosion by a factor of 50 tim samples. This sensitivity of pit formation is very challenging, but not impossible to model on the macrosca processing and treatment has a certain impact on secondary phases (distribution and impurities), it can b

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper, a computational framework was developed to study the effect of corrosion on the mecha of Mg samples. Corrosion is modeled by a mass-diffusion type model accounting for, in general, paralle uniform and localised corrosion. To model the statistical effects governing localised corrosion attacks, W is used. In our corrosion model, the overall loss of mass of a sample has to be prescribed (e.g., based o data) to normalise the spatially distributed mass fluxes in the corrosion model properly. The mechanic Mg is modeled by a state-of-the-art CPB plasticity model with a coupled damage model. This allows u Mg degradation in immersed samples reduces the mechanical strength over time. We performed a large rosion experiments and mechanical tests to validate our computational framework in a laboratory setting that our framework could predict for both tension and compression tests the experimentally observed los strength due to corrosion when using extremely sharp Weibull distributions representing pitting corrosion the strength loss due to corrosion, the reduced ductility could be numerically predicted.
Our study confirmed the importance to consider the surface/volume effect of the samples during corro numerical analysis. It was shown that the conversion of the volume mass loss data via the surface related depth can be an appropriate way to do so. With consideration of calibrated Weibull statistics (e.g. a = uniform–like corrosion, a < 0.1 approximates strong pitting events) the macroscopic mechanical behaviou material can be adequately computed. Adaption of the approach to otherMg alloys andmaterials suffering p is possible but requires carefulWeibull parameter calibration. A general limitation of our current computati is the need to prescribe the overall mass loss to calibrate the boundary conditions of the corrosion mode this limitation, in the future more sophisticated corrosion models are required that can predict the rate of geometry and material of the sample as well as the chemical properties of its environment are given. Such a corrosion model could, for example, rely on a phase-field approach or a peridynamics approach [13, 42].

sections.text:
The authors like to thank Danny Mangels for his diligent scripting and model calibration, Jürgen Mark Erdmann for their assistance during mechanical testing, Mohammad Mavi Mashadi for providing exampl of his previous work, and Rainer Falkenberg for fruitful discussions. The advices of Annette Havelberg o are very much appreciated.
